Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Neutrino Physics Research at the University of Minnesota Duluth
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports work to understand neutrinos: the smallest but most common massive particle in the universe. Although there are a billion neutrinos for every more well-known electron or proton, neutrinos interact only via the so-called "weak" force: so they rarely bump into anything, even the detectors designed to study them. That means they are also the least well understood of the fundamental particles. Work at Univ. of Minnesota Duluth studies neutrino interactions with normal matter, how they change or "oscillate" as they travel along, and the astrophysical sources of neutrinos. The intellectual merit for this proposal is the that these experiments will bring us to further knowledge of three critical parameters needed to understand neutrinos: the determination of the neutrino mass hierarchy, or how the masses of the three neutrinos relate to each other, improved measurements of the mass-squared difference of the three masses and mixing parameters that determine how the three alternate with each other, and vastly improved measurements of neutrino cross sections.

Faculty and students working on the NOvA experiment will further the oscillation measurements and are working toward first astrophysics results. The effort includes enhancing the ability for NOvA electronics to self-detect the neutrino burst from a potential galactic supernova and share that alert with the world-wide supernova detection network. Neutrino interaction measurements continue with existing and incoming data from the MINERvA experiment. Finally, the group is pursuing work toward the next generation experiment, DUNE, including roles in the data acquisition system, design of the near detectors, and the role of neutrino interaction uncertainties in the design sensitivity of the experiment. This grant also supports broader impacts via participation and leadership of the Soudan + NOvA outreach program, which includes regular summer tours of the Soudan Underground Laboratory and the NOvA detector at the Ash River, MN site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by this award, the Duluth group has achieved our proposed and some stretch goals.   We deployed a supernova neutrino trigger for the NOvA long-baseline neutrino experiment and will imminently tie it into the SNEWS world-wide supernova alert network.   The challenge was to pick out small interaction signals from enormous cosmic ray backgrounds (see image 1).  We have produced especially innovative results from the MINERvA neutrino interaction experiment data, extending the energy and momentum transfer analysis to anti-neutrino interactions, and making newly observed interactions with two-nucleon knockout part the MINERvA reference simulation.   Then we also made the first ever measurements of neutrons resulting from anti-neutrino reactions on carbon and hydrogen (see image 2).   A number of technical improvements were incorporated into the NOvA and MINERvA analyses and the GENIE neutrino interaction model codebase used by hundreds of researchers.   They range from speed and convenience (NOvA front-end data selection with Machine Learning), critical improvements to the reference simulation for MINERvA, and a fix to a core routine in GENIE that affects multiple experiments doing the most advanced (transverse kinematic imbalance) analyses.  Several undergraduate and collaborative projects have pushed toward cosmic ray papers using both the final MINOS/MINOS+ dataset and the initial NOvA data (near and far detectors).

The scope of work for this grant also included preparation steps for future work, both with the current experiments mentioned above and the next generation DUNE experiment.   Habig is a leader in the specification of (and writing the technical design report for) DUNE's data acquisition system, building on his work with NOvA.   The requirements are being driven by supernova neutrino detection, will encompass proton decay physics, and will allow DUNE to achieve much more physics reach than current long-baseline experiments.    Gran is responsible for an unusually large fraction of the physics topics using MINERvA data and other experiments that follow our lead.   Future Duluth work on using machine learning to measure hadron multiplicity, observation of remnant nucleus deexcitation from neutrino-carbon reactions, and an innovative energy dependence analysis are being prepared for use with MINERvA's newest data sets.

Because MINERvA as a whole, and the Duluth-based contributions in particular, are both foundational and world leading, we have aggressively pushed physics, technical, and code-level developments to the broader community.   Consumers include the operating experiments T2K, NoVA, MicroBooNE, and the future DUNE experiment.   The Duluth-specific products include the two publications mentioned above (anti-neutrino momentum transfer and anti-neutrino neutron activity).  We also produced two public technical notes this grant period, both accompanied by code, to allow other groups to use the quasielastic RPA effect and its uncertainty, and use elastic rescattering effects in GENIE.   Code for the multinucleon tune to MINERvA data used throughout current MINERvA analyses was shared and a publication describing the tuning procedure and limitations is in preparation.

Duluth is a primarily undergraduate institution, so the students whose work was central to these results are  undergraduates and masters students.  Five undergraduates and seven masters students gained valuable research skills while working on these projects over this grant cycle.  They have taken their new skills and experience into both PhD programs and private industry.  We also assisted non-Duluth Ph.D. students in our collaborations in extending the work of previous Duluth students into these new data sets and into the new physics reach.
